headings.value: Getting access to the Cloudflare API

children.value: Getting access to the Cloudflare API

Using the Cloudflare API, requires authentication so that Cloudflare knows who is making requests and what permissions they have. An API Token can be created to grant access to the API to perform actions. See

Legacy Note: Existing customers may be familiar with API Keys. These allow for less granular access and each user can only have one. For these reasons, we advice customers using API Keys to transition to using API Tokens.
Once you have your API Token created, all API requests are authorized in the same way. Cloudflare uses the
interface. When used in an example Cloudflare API request it looks like this:
The above example is just that, an example. Never send anyone or store you API Token secret in plaintext. Also be sure not to check it into code repositories especially public ones like on github.
For specific guidance on making API calls, see the following:
for a service for how to guides.
for request and response payloads for each endpoint.
you can leverage our 1st party libraries to integrate with Cloudflare's API.
for documentation of all of Cloudflare's API endpoints.
All documentation in the Cloudflare Workers documentation website, including reference documentation and tutorials, are licensed under the
for this project will be licensed under CC-BY-SA 4.0: thanks for your contributions!
Code contributions, such as snippets in the
and the code that serves this website via Cloudflare Workers, are licensed under the
To get started creating an API Token, log into the
. From the API Token home screen select

If you are new to API Tokens or the Cloudflare API, Templates are the quickest way to get started. If you think a specific template matches your needs, go ahead and select it. You will be able to further customize the template after selecting it. If no template matches your use case or you want to build the token from scratch, select
template has been selected. After selecting, you are presented with a view of the currently selected permissions. There are 3 required inputs to creating a Token:
The permissions granted to the token
The resources the token can affect
There are two additional inputs that can be used to restrict how a token is used. These are
. Both of these are covered in Advance Usage under

Because a template was selected, both the name and the permissions have been pre-selected. In the case of a custom token, both of inputs one and two would need to be filled in. the only required selection is which zones the token should belong to. Let's cover each of these sections.
This can be anything text and should be informative of why or how the token is being used as a reference.
Permissions are segmented into three categories based on resource:

Each category contains Permission Groups related to those resources. DNS permissions belong to the Zone category, while Billing permissions belong to the Account category. A full list of the Permission Groups can be
After selecting a Permission Group, you can choose what level of access to grant the token. Most groups offer
The resources selected will be the only ones that the token will be able to perform the authorized actions against. For example granting
will allow the token to read DNS records for only that specific zone. Any other zone will return an error for DNS record reads operations. Any other operation on that zone will also return an error.

As permissions are selected in resource categories, options for selecting the appropriate resources will appear. Note that for user permissions, there is no necessary selection as the token will operate on the user creating the token.
When creating tokens with access to zone resources there are multiple ways to define the access. The options available are:
All zones from a specific account - ex: All zones belonging to the account named
All zones in all accounts. This grants access to every zone you have access to. Exercise caution when granting permissions this widely.
Note: When selections of option 2 or 3 are included, then excluding zones can be used to "allow all" zones as defined except specific zones.
For this example, we go with option 1 and select the zone
Account resources are similar to zone resources but with 1 less option:
A specific account - ex: My Production Account.
All accounts. This would be all the accounts the user has access to.
Once you have selected the appropriate permissions and resources, select
to review the token before creating.
The token summary screen allows you to see all the resources and permissions the token will have before creating the token and seeing the token's secret.
If there are any issues you can go back and make adjustments. Even if after creating and using the token modifications need to be made, a token can be edited after creation.
Once you have verified the token is as desired, select
to proceed to generating the Token's secret.
Once successfully generated, the token secret is only shown once. Make sure to copy the secret to a secure place.
Do not store the secret in plaintext where others may be able to access it. Anyone with this token can perform the authorized actions against the resources the token has been granted access to.
This screen also includes an example command to test the token (reproduced below). The
endpoint allows fetching the current status of the given token.
With this you have successfully created an API Token and can now start working with the Cloudflare API!

If the secret is lost or believed to be compromised, you can either create a new token or your token can be rolled to generate a new secret. Rolling your secret key into a new one will invalidate the previous secret, but the access and permissions will be the same as the previous key.
Next to the API token you wish to roll, click the
to continue and you will see a new API token secret key.
Below is a list of all the Token Permissions that are available to use. The current list can be

Grants write access to Cloudflare Access zone resources
Grants full access to Cloudflare Apps

Grants write access to Firewall resources
Grants read access to load balancers and associated resources
Grants write access to load balancers and associated resources
Grants read access to logs and logpush jobs

headings.value: Creating API tokens via the API

children.value: Creating API tokens via the API

With API Tokens it is possible to be able to generate new tokens on the fly via the API. Doing so requires creating an API Token in the UI with the ability to create subsequent tokens. This page walks through how to create the seed token, and then creating API Tokens via the API
Before you can create Tokens via the API you need to generate the initial Token which will have the ability to do so via the Cloudflare Dashboard. From the
Template. This template will contain the user permission for creating API Tokens. This allows you to mimic the exact behavior presented in the UI from the API.
It is highly recommended when using this template to not grant other permissions to the token. This token should be safeguarded given it can create tokens with access to any resource the user has.
Limiting the use of the token via IP filtering or TTL is also recommended to reduce the potential for abuse in the event that the token is compromised. See
Creating API tokens with the API
Once an API Token is created that can create other tokens, the next step is using it in the API. The complete API schema docs for these operations are
, but below is a walkthrough of the process to create a token with the API.
Creating a Token requires defining two sections of config and then sending the API request.
A Access Policy defines what resources the token can act on and what permissions it has to those resources. If you have created tokens in the UI, you will notice similarities in how this works.
Let's look at an example Token's policy. Each token can contain multiple policies.
Now to define each field of the policy:
- This is a unique identifier for the policy generated after creation and is read-only
- Whether this policy is allowing or denying access. If only creating 1 policy then
should be used. The evaluation order for policies is as follows:
- This is where you define what resources are allowed to be configured. More detail below.
- This defines what permissions will the policy grant to the included resources. More detail below.
Currently API Token Policies support 3 resource types:
can be fetched by calling the appropriate
can be included in a token policy.
can be included in a token policy:
For user resources, the only option is referencing one's self which is done with:
The last piece to defining a policy is what Permission Groups should be applied. You can see the full list of permission groups either in
. It is only required to pass the
of the permission group in the policy. Permission Groups are scoped to specific resources, so a permission group in a policy will only apply to the resource type it is scoped for.
Last in defining the token is setting up any limitations on how the token can be used. Currently, API Tokens allow for IP filtering and TTLs. You can find general info in
When defining TTLs you can set the time at which a token becomes active,
and the time when it expires,
. Both of these fields take timestamps in UTC in the following format:
Limiting usage of a token by IP filters is defined with the following object:
objects must be in CIDR notation. For example, specifying a single IP would be
Putting this all together we can now create a token like so:
This section covers two advanced use cases with API Tokens:
API Tokens can be restricted at runtime in two ways:
IP Restrictions control which IP address API requests with this token can and cannot be made from. By default, if no filtering is applied the the token can be used from all addresses. Once an
rule is applied the token can only be used from the IPs defined. Ranges can be defined with
. If allowing an IP range with exceptions is required then a
can be defined to exempt specific IPs or smaller ranges.
By default, tokens don't expire. They are long lived. Defining a TTL allows for setting when a token starts being valid and when a token is no longer valid. This is often referred to as
. Setting these timestamps will limit the lifetime of the token to the defined period. Not setting the start date or
means the token is active as soon as it is created. Not setting the end date or
means the token does not expire.
Note: Dates selected are defined as 00:00 UTC of that day. For finer grained time selection, please use the
API Keys are the legacy authorization scheme for talking to Cloudflare's APIs.
API Keys have multiple limitations when compared to API Tokens:
- API Keys have access to all the resources of the user. This makes it impossible to safely use API Keys for access to non-production resources when a user also has access to production resources.
- Similar to (1), API Keys have the exact same permissions as the user which means if the user can delete zones, or change DNS records so can the key.

- Only one API Key can be provisioned per user. This complicates using Cloudflare's API in production systems where maintaining two secrets for accessing the API is important in the case 1 needs to be rolled.
Lack of advanced limits on usage
- API Tokens can be limited to use in specific time windows and expire or be limited to use from specific IP ranges.

For these reasons, API Keys are not recommended for new customers. Current customers using API Keys are encouraged to migrate and use API Tokens instead. You can find information about using API Keys in the
Log in to the Cloudflare dashboard.
section, view or change either of your API keys:
: Serves as your main API key.
: Only used when creating origin certificates using the API.
To access your Host API Key (needed for the Hosting Partner API), log into the
. If you would like to become a Hosting partner,
When you use the Cloudflare API, you need to authenticate your requests so we know who you are and what permissions you have.
When possible, use API tokens to interact with the Cloudflare API.
Though you can still use API keys to access the Cloudflare API, these keys have
that make them less secure than API tokens.
